displaytitle: Caricature of a Man in Slippers and Wig Seen from the Rear
medium: Pen and brown ink with brush and brown wash
creditline: Bequest of Dan Fellows Platt, Class of 1895
markings: Stamps in ink, on verso lower left: D.F.P. [in circle] [Lugt 750a] [and] P [in diamond shape] [Lugt 2066b]

makers.displaydate: 1696–1770; born Venice, Italy; died Madrid, Spain
makers.displaymaker: Giovanni Battista Tiepolo, 1696–1770; born Venice, Italy; died Madrid, Spain
formerly attributed to Domenico Tiepolo, Italian, 1727–1804

texts.textentryhtml: Many of Tiepolo’s caricature figures have proportions gently distorted in a mode of wry humor. The artist’s sweeping pen lines define features and contours in swift strokes, with the diluted wash used economically to capture effects of light and of volume. Here, a diminutive figure in a long dressing gown is bewigged but still in his slippers, his short legs planted on turned-out feet. The view from behind is also common in caricatures, allowing for robustly undignified or wittily gauche images that deflate the public persona of the subject.
